message_1: Consider the formula A ⊸ ¬B in linear logic, where A and B are propositions. Evaluate the formula when A is true and B is false.
message_2:
In linear logic, the formula A ⊸ ¬B can be read as "A implies not B." To evaluate this formula when A is true and B is false, we can substitute the given values into the formula:

True ⊸ ¬False

In classical logic, ¬False is equivalent to True. Therefore, the formula becomes:

True ⊸ True

In linear logic, A ⊸ B is true if either A is false or B is true. In this case, both A and B are true, so the formula evaluates to:

True

Thus, the formula A ⊸ ¬B is true when A is true and B is false.
